sections.procedure:
1.  The case originated in three applications against Ukraine lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by three Ukrainian nationals: Mr Mikhail Igorevich Belyayev (“the first applicant” application no. 34345/10, lodged on 3 March 2010), Mr Ivan Ivanovych Karpenko (“the second applicant” – application no. 50687/10, lodged on 16 August 2010) and Mr Rustam Zakirovich Farziyev (“the third applicant” – application no. 70492/13, lodged on 28 October 2013).
2.  The first applicant was represented by Mr T. Kalmykov, a lawyer practising in Kharkiv. The second applicant, who was granted legal aid, was represented by Ms H. Ovdiienko, a lawyer practising in Kharkiv, and the third applicant, who was also granted legal aid, was represented by Ms N. Okhotnikova, a lawyer practising in Kyiv. The Ukrainian Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, Mr I. Lishchyna.
3.  The applicants complained under Article 14 of the Convention, read in conjunction with Article 8 of the Convention, of discrimination due to differing visiting rights which had been laid down by the domestic legislation in respect of male and female life prisoners.
4.  On 16 May 2018 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the applications was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
5.  The Government objected to the examination of the applications by a Committee, but provided no reasons. After having considered the Government’s objection, the Court rejects it.
sections.circumstances:
6.  The first, second and third applicants were born in 1981, 1973 and 1984 respectively. Since 2004 they have been serving life sentences in correctional colonies in Ukraine.
7.  On 11 July 2003 the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine (“the Code”). Article 150 of the Code (“Place of serving life imprisonment”) provided that life prisoners were to serve their sentences in maximum-security correctional colonies. Article 151 (“Procedure for, and conditions of, the execution and serving of life sentences”) further provided, inter alia , that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months. No reference to prisoners’ gender was made in those Articles. At the same time, Article 18 (“Correctional colonies”) provided that female life prisoners were to serve their sentences in medium-security colonies. In turn, Article 139 (“Medium-security correctional colonies”) provided that prisoners serving their sentences in such colonies were entitled, inter alia , to have one short visit every month and one long visit every three months. Article 110 specified that a short visit from relatives or other persons could last for up to four hours and a long visit from close relatives could last for up to three days.
8.  By a letter of 27 June 2007 the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant, in reply to a letter sent by him on an earlier date, that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months, as provided by Article 139 of the Code, given that they served their sentences in medium-security colonies, as provided by Article 18 of the Code. Referring, in particular, to Article 151 of the Code, the Department further stated that male life prisoners were entitled to have one short visit every six months and that they were not entitled to have long visits.
9.  On 21 January 2010 the Code was amended (“the 2010 amendments”). Article 150, as amended, stated that persons sentenced to life imprisonment were to serve their sentences as follows: male prisoners  either in maximum-security sectors of medium-security correctional colonies or in maximum-security correctional colonies; and female prisoners – either in medium-security sectors of minimum-security correctional colonies with general conditions of detention or in medium-security correctional colonies. Article 151, as amended, stated that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every three months. A newly introduced Article 151² (“Specifics regarding the serving of sentences by female life prisoners”) provided that female life prisoners were to be placed, as a rule, in medium-security sectors of minimum-security colonies with general conditions of detention. It also provided that female life prisoners were to be subject to the regime laid down for prisoners held in mediumsecurity colonies (that is, the regime provided for in Article 139 of the Code).
10.  By the Law of 8 April 2014 on the introduction of amendments to the Code relating to the adaptation of status of convicted persons to European standards the Code was amended again (“the 2014 amendments”). Article 151 was amended to entitle all life prisoners to one short visit every month and one long visit every three months regardless of the type of correctional colony in which they were detained or the security regime to which they were subject.
11.  Further amendments to Article 151 of the Code, which were passed by Parliament on 7 September 2016, entitled all life prisoners to one long visit every two months.
12.  The first applicant stated that he and his family had wished to maintain their relationships, but as the result of the absence of the right to long visits until 2014 he had had to divorce his wife. His father, grandfather and grandmother had died in 2008, 2009 and 2014 respectively and he had not been able to see them while serving his sentence. The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the first applicant had received twenty-eight short visits on unspecified dates and fifteen long visits (between 17 March 2015 and 6 July 2018) from his new wife, mother and his other grandmother.
13.  The second applicant stated that, because of the lack of the opportunity to have long visits until 2014, he had lost contact with his family. His relatives had died – in particular he referred to his father having died in 2012 – and when the 2014 amendments entitled him to long visits, there had no longer been anyone to visit him. The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the second applicant had had one short visit in 2005 (from his sister) and had not requested any long visits.
14.  The third applicant stated that, in the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, his right to found a family had been more declaratory than effective as, in particular, he had not been able to have any physical contact in order to conceive children. The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the third applicant had had twelve short visits (between 25 July 2012 and 26 December 2017) and fourteen long visits (between 5 August 2014 and 6 February 2018) from his wife, mother, father and friends.

events.source_text: The case originated in three applications against Ukraine lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by three Ukrainian nationals: Mr Mikhail Igorevich Belyayev (“the first applicant” application no. 34345/10, lodged on 3 March 2010), Mr Ivan Ivanovych Karpenko (“the second applicant” – application no. 50687/10, lodged on 16 August 2010) and Mr Rustam Zakirovich Farziyev (“the third applicant” – application no. 70492/13, lodged on 28 October 2013.

The first applicant was represented by Mr T. Kalmykov, a lawyer practising in Kharkiv. The second applicant, who was granted legal aid, was represented by Ms H. Ovdiienko, a lawyer practising in Kharkiv, and the third applicant, who was also granted legal aid, was represented by Ms N. Okhotnikova, a lawyer practising in Kyiv. The Ukrainian Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, Mr I. Lishchyna.
events.event_who: Mr T. Kalmykov, Ms H. Ovdiienko, Ms N. Okhotnikova, Mr I. Lishchyna

events.source_text: The applicants complained under Article 14 of the Convention, read in conjunction with Article 8 of the Convention, of discrimination due to differing visiting rights which had been laid down by the domestic legislation in respect of male and female life prisoners.
On 16 May 2018 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the applications was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
The Government objected to the examination of the applications by a Committee, but provided no reasons. After having considered the Government’s objection, the Court rejects it.
The first, second and third applicants were born in 1981, 1973 and 1984 respectively. Since 2004 they have been serving life sentences in correctional colonies in Ukraine.
events.event_who: The first, second and third applicants

events.source_text: On 11 July 2003 the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine (“the Code”). Article 150 of the Code (“Place of serving life imprisonment”) provided that life prisoners were to serve their sentences in maximum-security correctional colonies. Article 151 (“Procedure for, and conditions of, the execution and serving of life sentences”) further provided, inter alia , that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months. No reference to prisoners’ gender was made in those Articles.

By a letter of 27 June 2007 the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant, in reply to a letter sent by him on an earlier date, that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months, as provided by Article 139 of the Code, given that they served their sentences in medium-security colonies, as provided by Article 18 of the Code. Referring, in particular, to Article 151 of the Code, the Department further stated that male life prisoners were entitled to have one short visit every six months and that they were not entitled to have long visits.

On 21 January 2010 the Code was amended (“the 2010 amendments”). Article 150, as amended, stated that persons sentenced to life imprisonment were to serve their sentences as follows: male prisoners either in maximum-security sectors of medium-security correctional colonies or in maximum-security correctional colonies; and female prisoners – either in medium-security sectors of minimum-security correctional colonies with general conditions of detention or in medium-security correctional colonies. Article 151, as amended, stated that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every three months. A newly introduced Article 151² (“Specifics regarding the serving of sentences by female life prisoners”) provided that female life prisoners were to be placed, as a rule, in medium-security sectors of minimum-security colonies with general conditions of detention. It also provided that female life prisoners were to be subject to the regime laid down for prisoners held in mediumsecurity colonies (that is, the regime provided for in Article 139 of the Code).

By the Law of 8 April 2014 on the introduction of amendments to the Code relating to the adaptation of status of convicted persons to European standards the Code was amended again (“the 2014 amendments”). Article 151 was amended to entitle all life prisoners to one short visit every month and one long visit every three months regardless of the type of correctional colony in which they were detained or the security regime to which they were subject.
Further amendments to Article 151 of the Code, which were passed by Parliament on 7 September 2016, entitled all life prisoners to one long visit every two months.

The first applicant stated that he and his family had wished to maintain their relationships, but as the result of the absence of the right to long visits until 2014 he had had to divorce his wife. His father, grandfather and grandmother had died in 2008, 2009 and 2014 respectively and he had not been able to see them while serving his sentence. The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the first applicant had received twenty-eight short visits on unspecified dates and fifteen long visits (between 17 March 2015 and 6 July 2018) from his new wife, mother and his other grandmother.

The second applicant stated that, because of the lack of the opportunity to have long visits until 2014, he had lost contact with his family. His relatives had died – in particular he referred to his father having died in 2012 – and when the 2014 amendments entitled him to long visits, there had no longer been anyone to visit him. The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the second applicant had had one short visit in 2005 (from his sister) and had not requested any long visits.

The third applicant stated that, in the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, his right to found a family had been more declaratory than effective as, in particular, he had not been able to have any physical contact in order to conceive children. The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the third applicant had had twelve short visits (between 25 July 2012 and 26 December 2017) and fourteen long visits (between 5 August 2014 and 6 February 2018) from his wife, mother, father and friends.

FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, 1. Decides to join the applications; 2. Declares the applications admissible; 3. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 14 of the Convention, read in conjunction with Article 8 of the Convention; 4. Holds (a) that the respondent State is to pay, within three months, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement: (i) EUR 3,000 (three thousand euros) to the first applicant and EUR 1,500 (one thousand five hundred euros) each to the second and third applicants, plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of nonpecuniary damage; (ii) EUR 850 (eight hundred and fifty euros) to the first applicant, plus any tax that may be chargeable to him, in respect of his costs and expenses, to be paid directly to the account of Mr T. Kalmykov; (b) that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
Dismisses the remainder of the applicants’ claims for just satisfaction.

The case originated in three applications against Ukraine lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by three Ukrainian nationals: Mr Mikhail Igorevich Belyayev (“the first applicant” application no. 34345/10, lodged on 3 March 2010), Mr Ivan Ivanovych Karpenko (“the second applicant” – application no. 50687/10, lodged on 16 August 2010) and Mr Rustam Zakirovich Farziyev (“the third applicant” – application no. 70492/13, lodged on 28 October 2013).

The Government objected to the examination of the applications by a Committee, but provided no reasons. After having considered the Government’s objection, the Court rejects it.

By a letter of 27 June 2007 the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant, in reply to a letter sent by him on an earlier date, that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months, as provided by Article 139 of the Code, given that they served their sentences in medium-security colonies, as provided by Article 18 of the Code.
events.event_who: State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences

events.source_text: On 21 January 2010 the Code was amended (“the 2010 amendments”).

By the Law of 8 April 2014 on the introduction of amendments to the Code relating to the adaptation of status of convicted persons to European standards the Code was amended again (“the 2014 amendments”).
Further amendments to Article 151 of the Code, which were passed by Parliament on 7 September 2016, entitled all life prisoners to one long visit every two months.
Decides to join the applications;
Declares the applications admissible;
Holds that there has been a violation of Article 14 of the Convention, read in conjunction with Article 8 of the Convention;
Holds that the respondent State is to pay, within three months, the following amounts…
Dismisses the remainder of the applicants’ claims for just satisfaction.

The case originated in three applications against Ukraine lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ("the Convention") by three Ukrainian nationals: Mr Mikhail Igorevich Belyayev ("the first applicant" application no. 34345/10, lodged on 3 March 2010), Mr Ivan Ivanovych Karpenko ("the second applicant" – application no. 50687/10, lodged on 16 August 2010) and Mr Rustam Zakirovich Farziyev ("the third applicant" – application no. 70492/13, lodged on 28 October 2013).

events.source_text: On 16 May 2018 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the applications was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
The Government objected to the examination of the applications by a Committee, but provided no reasons. After having considered the Government’s objection, the Court rejects it.
On 11 July 2003 the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine ("the Code").

By a letter of 27 June 2007 the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant, in reply to a letter sent by him on an earlier date, that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months, as provided by Article 139 of the Code, given that they served their sentences in medium-security colonies, as provided by Article 18 of the Code.
events.event_who: State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences, second applicant

events.source_text: On 21 January 2010 the Code was amended ("the 2010 amendments").

By the Law of 8 April 2014 on the introduction of amendments to the Code relating to the adaptation of status of convicted persons to European standards the Code was amended again ("the 2014 amendments").
Further amendments to Article 151 of the Code, which were passed by Parliament on 7 September 2016, entitled all life prisoners to one long visit every two months.

FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, 1. Decides to join the applications; 2. Declares the applications admissible; 3. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 14 of the Convention, read in conjunction with Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event_what: decides to join applications, declares admissible, holds violation

events.source_text: 4. Holds (a) that the respondent State is to pay, within three months, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement: (i) EUR 3,000 (three thousand euros) to the first applicant and EUR 1,500 (one thousand five hundred euros) each to the second and third applicants, plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of non-pecuniary damage;
Done in English, and notified in writing on 6 June 2019, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.

events.source_text: By a letter of 27 June 2007 the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant, in reply to a letter sent by him on an earlier date, that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months, as provided by Article 139 of the Code.
events.event_who: State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences
events.event_what: informing the second applicant about visiting rights for female life prisoners

events.source_text: Further, by a letter sent on an earlier date to the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences, the second applicant had asked whether he was entitled to long visits.
events.event_what: asking about his visiting rights via a letter sent earlier

events.source_text: By the Law of 8 April 2014 on the introduction of amendments to the Code relating to the adaptation of status of convicted persons to European standards the Code was amended again (“the 2014 amendments”). Article 151 was amended to entitle all life prisoners to one short visit every month and one long visit every three months regardless of the type of correctional colony in which they were detained or the security regime to which they were subject.
events.event_what: amending Article 151 of the Code to provide equal visiting rights for all life prisoners regardless of colony type or security regime

events.source_text: Further amendments to Article 151 of the Code, which were passed by Parliament on 7 September 2016, entitled all life prisoners to one long visit every two months.
events.event_what: further amending Article 151 to provide for one long visit every two months

events.source_text: On 6 June 2019, the Court notified the parties of its decision.
events.event_what: notifying the parties about its decision regarding just satisfaction

events.source_text: The first applicant stated that he and his family had wished to maintain their relationships, but as the result of the absence of the right to long visits until 2014 he had had to divorce his wife. His father, grandfather and grandmother had died in 2008, 2009 and 2014 respectively and he had not been able to see them while serving his sentence.
events.event_when: not specified (but mentioned divorcing wife due to lack of long visits until 2014)
events.event_what: stating that the absence of long visits caused him to divorce his wife and prevented him from seeing family members before their death

events.source_text: The second applicant stated that, because of the lack of the opportunity to have long visits until 2014, he had lost contact with his family. His relatives had died – in particular he referred to his father having died in 2012 – and when the 2014 amendments entitled him to long visits, there had no longer been anyone to visit him.
events.event_when: not specified (but referenced lack of opportunity until 2014)
events.event_what: stating that the lack of long visits caused loss of contact with family and prevented him from visiting them after their death

events.source_text: The third applicant stated that, in the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, his right to found a family had been more declaratory than effective as, in particular, he had not been able to have any physical contact in order to conceive children.
events.event_what: stating that the lack of long visits prevented him from having physical contact to conceive children, making his right to found a family ineffective

events.source_text: The Court decided to join the applications.
events.event_what: joining all three applications together for examination

events.source_text: The Court declared the applications admissible.
events.event_what: admitting all three applications for examination before the Court

events.source_text: The Court held that there has been a violation of Article 14 of the Convention, read in conjunction with Article 8 of the Convention.
events.event_what: finding that there was a violation under Articles 14 and 8 of the Convention due to discrimination

events.source_text: The Court ordered the respondent State to pay certain amounts.
events.event_what: ordering the Ukrainian Government to pay EUR 3,000 to first applicant and EUR 1,500 each to second and third applicants for nonpecuniary damage, plus simple interest

events.source_text: The Court dismissed the remainder of the applicants’ claims for just satisfaction.
events.event_what: dismissing other parts of the claim regarding additional just satisfaction

events.source_text: The case originated in three applications against Ukraine lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ("the Convention") by three Ukrainian nationals: Mr Mikhail Igorevich Belyayev ("the first applicant" application no. 34345/10, lodged on 3 March 2010), Mr Ivan Ivanovych Karpenko ("the second applicant" – application no. 50687/10, lodged on 16 August 2010) and Mr Rustam Zakirovich Farziyev ("the third applicant" – application no. 70492/13, lodged on 28 October 2013).
events.event: The case originated in three applications against Ukraine.
events.event_when: lodged on 3 March 2010, lodged on 16 August 2010, lodged on 28 October 2013

events.source_text: The first applicant was represented by Mr T. Kalmykov, a lawyer practising in Kharkiv.
events.event: The first applicant was represented by Mr T. Kalmykov.

events.source_text: The second applicant, who was granted legal aid, was represented by Ms H. Ovdiienko, a lawyer practising in Kharkiv, and the third applicant, who was also granted legal aid, was represented by Ms N. Okhotnikova, a lawyer practising in Kyiv.
events.event: The second and third applicants were represented by their respective lawyers.
events.event_who: Ms H. Ovdiienko, Ms N. Okhotnikova

events.source_text: The Ukrainian Government ("the Government") were represented by their Agent, Mr I. Lishchyna.
events.event: The Ukrainian Government were represented by Mr I. Lishchyna.

events.source_text: The applicants complained under Article 14 of the Convention, read in conjunction with Article 8 of the Convention, of discrimination due to differing visiting rights which had been laid down by the domestic legislation in respect of male and female life prisoners.
events.event: The applicants complained of discrimination due to differing visiting rights.
events.event_what: complained under Article 14, read in conjunction with Article 8

events.source_text: On 16 May 2018 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the applications was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event: Notice of the complaints was given to the Government, and the remainder of the applications were declared inadmissible.

events.source_text: The Government objected to the examination of the applications by a Committee, but provided no reasons.
events.event: The Government objected to the examination of the applications by a Committee.

events.source_text: After having considered the Government’s objection, the Court rejects it.
events.event: The Court rejects the Government's objection.

events.source_text: The first, second and third applicants were born in 1981, 1973 and 1984 respectively.
events.event: The applicants' birth years were provided.

events.source_text: Since 2004 they have been serving life sentences in correctional colonies in Ukraine.
events.event: The applicants have been serving life sentences since 2004.

events.source_text: On 11 July 2003 the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine ("the Code").
events.event: The Code on the Execution of Sentences was adopted by the Ukrainian Parliament.

events.source_text: Article 150 of the Code ("Place of serving life imprisonment") provided that life prisoners were to serve their sentences in maximum-security correctional colonies.
events.event: Article 150 of the Code provided that life prisoners were to serve their sentences in maximum-security correctional colonies.

events.source_text: Article 151 ("Procedure for, and conditions of, the execution and serving of life sentences") further provided, inter alia , that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months.
events.event: Article 151 provided that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months.

events.source_text: At the same time, Article 18 ("Correctional colonies") provided that female life prisoners were to serve their sentences in medium-security colonies.
events.event: Article 18 provided that female life prisoners were to serve their sentences in medium-security colonies.

events.source_text: In turn, Article 139 ("Medium-security correctional colonies") provided that prisoners serving their sentences in such colonies were entitled, inter alia , to have one short visit every month and one long visit every three months.
events.event: Article 139 provided that prisoners serving their sentences in medium-security colonies were entitled to have one short visit every month and one long visit every three months.

events.source_text: Article 110 specified that a short visit from relatives or other persons could last for up to four hours and a long visit from close relatives could last for up to three days.
events.event: Article 110 specified the duration of short and long visits.

events.source_text: By a letter of 27 June 2007 the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant, in reply to a letter sent by him on an earlier date, that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months, as provided by Article 139 of the Code, given that they served their sentences in medium-security colonies, as provided by Article 18 of the Code.
events.event: The State Department informed the second applicant about visiting rights for female life prisoners.

events.source_text: Referring, in particular, to Article 151 of the Code, the Department further stated that male life prisoners were entitled to have one short visit every six months and that they were not entitled to have long visits.
events.event: The Department stated visiting rights for male life prisoners, referring to Article 151.

events.source_text: On 21 January 2010 the Code was amended ("the 2010 amendments").

Article 150, as amended, stated that persons sentenced to life imprisonment were to serve their sentences as follows: male prisoners either in maximum-security sectors of medium-security correctional colonies or in maximum-security correctional colonies; and female prisoners – either in medium-security sectors of minimum-security correctional colonies with general conditions of detention or in medium-security correctional colonies.
events.event: Article 150, as amended, stated the serving locations for life imprisonment sentences.

events.source_text: Article 151, as amended, stated that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every three months.
events.event: Article 151, as amended, stated visiting rights for life prisoners.

events.source_text: A newly introduced Article 151² ("Specifics regarding the serving of sentences by female life prisoners") provided that female life prisoners were to be placed, as a rule, in medium-security sectors of minimum-security colonies with general conditions of detention.
events.event: Article 151² provided that female life prisoners were to be placed in minimum-security sectors.

events.source_text: It also provided that female life prisoners were to be subject to the regime laid down for prisoners held in medium-security colonies (that is, the regime provided for in Article 139 of the Code).
events.event: The regime for female life prisoners was specified.

events.source_text: By the Law of 8 April 2014 on the introduction of amendments to the Code relating to the adaptation of status of convicted persons to European standards the Code was amended again ("the 2014 amendments").
events.event: The Code was amended again in 2014.

events.source_text: Article 151 was amended to entitle all life prisoners to one short visit every month and one long visit every three months regardless of the type of correctional colony in which they were detained or the security regime to which they were subject.
events.event: Article 151 was amended to entitle all life prisoners to monthly short visits and three-monthly long visits.

events.source_text: Further amendments to Article 151 of the Code, which were passed by Parliament on 7 September 2016, entitled all life prisoners to one long visit every two months.
events.event: Article 151 was further amended in 2016 to entitle all life prisoners to bi-monthly long visits.

events.source_text: The first applicant stated that he and his family had wished to maintain their relationships, but as the result of the absence of the right to long visits until 2014 he had had to divorce his wife.
events.event: The first applicant stated that he had to divorce his wife due to the lack of long visits until 2014.

events.source_text: His father, grandfather and grandmother had died in 2008, 2009 and 2014 respectively and he had not been able to see them while serving his sentence.
events.event: The first applicant could not see his family members who passed away during his sentence.

events.source_text: The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the first applicant had received twenty-eight short visits on unspecified dates and fifteen long visits (between 17 March 2015 and 6 July 2018) from his new wife, mother and his other grandmother.
events.event: The Government submitted that the first applicant received short and long visits during his sentence.

events.source_text: The second applicant stated that, because of the lack of the opportunity to have long visits until 2014, he had lost contact with his family.
events.event: The second applicant stated that he lost contact with his family due to the lack of long visits until 2014.

events.source_text: His relatives had died – in particular he referred to his father having died in 2012 – and when the 2014 amendments entitled him to long visits, there had no longer been anyone to visit him.
events.event: The second applicant's relatives had died, and when the 2014 amendments entitled him to long visits, there was no one left to visit him.

events.source_text: The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the second applicant had one short visit in 2005 (from his sister) and had not requested any long visits.
events.event: The Government submitted that the second applicant had one short visit in 2005 and did not request any long visits.

events.source_text: The third applicant stated that, in the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, his right to found a family had been more declaratory than effective as, in particular, he had not been able to have any physical contact in order to conceive children.
events.event: The third applicant stated that his right to found a family was affected due to the lack of long visits until 2014.

events.source_text: The Government submitted that while serving his sentence the third applicant had twelve short visits (between 25 July 2012 and 26 December 2017) and fourteen long visits (between 5 August 2014 and 6 February 2018) from his wife, mother, father and friends.
events.event: The Government submitted that the third applicant received short and long visits during his sentence.

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
events.event: The Court makes a unanimous decision for these reasons.

events.source_text: Decides to join the applications;
events.event: The Court decides to join the applications.

events.source_text: Declares the applications admissible;
events.event: The Court declares the applications admissible.

events.source_text: Holds that there has been a violation of Article 14 of the Convention, read in conjunction with Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event: The Court holds that there has been a violation of Articles 14 and 8.

events.source_text: Holds (a)  that the respondent State is to pay, within three months, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:
events.event: The Court holds that the respondent state is to pay certain amounts.

events.source_text: (i)  EUR 3,000 (three thousand euros) to the first applicant and EUR 1,500 (one thousand five hundred euros) each to the second and third applicants, plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of nonpecuniary damage;
events.event: The Court specifies the amounts to be paid for non-pecuniary damages.

events.source_text: (ii)  EUR 850 (eight hundred and fifty euros) to the first applicant, plus any tax that may be chargeable to him, in respect of his costs and expenses, to be paid directly to the account of Mr T. Kalmykov;
events.event: The Court specifies the amount to be paid for costs and expenses of the first applicant.

events.source_text: (b)  that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
events.event: The Court specifies the interest rate for the payments.

events.source_text: 5.   Dismisses the remainder of the applicants’ claims for just satisfaction.
events.event: The Court dismisses the remaining claims for just satisfaction.

events.source_text: Done in English, and notified in writing on 6 June 2019, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event: The decision is made in English, notified in writing, and follows the Rules of Court.

events.source_text: The case originated in three applications against Ukraine lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by three Ukrainian nationals: Mr Mikhail Igorevich Belyayev (“the first applicant” application no. 34345/10, lodged on 3 March 2010), Mr Ivan Ivanovych Karpenko (“the second applicant” – application no. 50687/10, lodged on 16 August 2010) and Mr Rustam Zakirovich Farziyev (“the third applicant” – application no. 70492/13, lodged on 28 October 2013).
The first applicant was represented by Mr T. Kalmykov, a lawyer practising in Kharkiv.

The second applicant, who was granted legal aid, was represented by Ms H. Ovdiienko, a lawyer practising in Kharkiv, and the third applicant, who was also granted legal aid, was represented by Ms N. Okhotnikova, a lawyer practising in Kyiv.
The Ukrainian Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, Mr I. Lishchyna.

The applicants complained under Article 14 of the Convention, read in conjunction with Article 8 of the Convention, of discrimination due to differing visiting rights which had been laid down by the domestic legislation in respect of male and female life prisoners.
On 16 May 2018 notice of the above complaints was given to the Government and the remainder of the applications was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
The Government objected to the examination of the applications by a Committee, but provided no reasons.
After having considered the Government’s objection, the Court rejects it.
The first, second and third applicants were born in 1981, 1973 and 1984 respectively.
Since 2004 they have been serving life sentences in correctional colonies in Ukraine.
On 11 July 2003 the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine (“the Code”).
Article 150 of the Code (“Place of serving life imprisonment”) provided that life prisoners were to serve their sentences in maximum-security correctional colonies.
Article 151 (“Procedure for, and conditions of, the execution and serving of life sentences”) further provided, inter alia, that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every six months.
Article 18 (“Correctional colonies”) provided that female life prisoners were to serve their sentences in medium-security colonies.

Article 139 (“Medium-security correctional colonies”) provided that prisoners serving their sentences in such colonies were entitled, inter alia, to have one short visit every month and one long visit every three months.
Article 110 specified that a short visit from relatives or other persons could last for up to four hours and a long visit from close relatives could last for up to three days.

By a letter of 27 June 2007 the State Department of Ukraine for the Execution of Sentences informed the second applicant, in reply to a letter sent by him on an earlier date, that female life prisoners were entitled to have one long visit every three months.
On 21 January 2010 the Code was amended (“the 2010 amendments”).

Article 150, as amended, stated that persons sentenced to life imprisonment were to serve their sentences as follows: male prisoners either in maximum-security sectors of medium-security correctional colonies or in maximum-security correctional colonies; and female prisoners – either in medium-security sectors of minimum-security correctional colonies with general conditions of detention or in medium-security correctional colonies.
Article 151, as amended, stated that life prisoners were entitled to one short visit every three months.

A newly introduced Article 151² (“Specifics regarding the serving of sentences by female life prisoners”) provided that female life prisoners were to be placed, as a rule, in medium-security sectors of minimum-security colonies with general conditions of detention.
It also provided that female life prisoners were to be subject to the regime laid down for prisoners held in medium-security colonies (that is, the regime provided for in Article 139 of the Code).

By the Law of 8 April 2014 on the introduction of amendments to the Code relating to the adaptation of status of convicted persons to European standards the Code was amended again (“the 2014 amendments”).

Article 151 was amended to entitle all life prisoners to one short visit every month and one long visit every three months regardless of the type of correctional colony in which they were detained or the security regime to which they were subject.
Further amendments to Article 151 of the Code, which were passed by Parliament on 7 September 2016, entitled all life prisoners to one long visit every two months.
The first applicant stated that he and his family had wished to maintain their relationships, but as the result of the absence of the right to long visits until 2014 he had had to divorce his wife.
His father, grandfather and grandmother had died in 2008, 2009 and 2014 respectively and he had not been able to see them while serving his sentence.
The second applicant stated that, because of the lack of the opportunity to have long visits until 2014, he had lost contact with his family.
His relatives had died – in particular he referred to his father having died in 2012 – and when the 2014 amendments entitled him to long visits, there had no longer been anyone to visit him.

The third applicant stated that, in the absence of the right to long visits until 2014, his right to found a family had been more declaratory than effective as, in particular, he had not been able to have any physical contact in order to conceive children.

FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, 1. Decides to join the applications; 2. Declares the applications admissible; 3. Holds that there has been a violation of Article 14 of the Convention, read in conjunction with Article 8 of the Convention;

4. Holds (a) that the respondent State is to pay, within three months, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement:

i) EUR 3,000 (three thousand euros) to the first applicant and EUR 1,500 (one thousand five hundred euros) each to the second and third applicants, plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of nonpecuniary damage;

ii) EUR 850 (eight hundred and fifty euros) to the first applicant, plus any tax that may be chargeable to him, in respect of his costs and expenses, to be paid directly to the account of Mr T. Kalmykov;

b) that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
5. Dismisses the remainder of the applicants’ claims for just satisfaction.
Done in English, and notified in writing on 6 June 2019, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.

The first, second and third applicants were born in 1981, 1973 and 1984 respectively. Since 2004 they have been serving life sentences in correctional colonies in Ukraine.
On 11 July 2003 the Ukrainian Parliament adopted the Code on the Execution of Sentences of Ukraine ("the Code").

events.event_what: join the applications; declares the applications admissible; holds that there has been a violation of Article 14 of the Convention, read in conjunction with Article 8 of the Convention; holds (a) that the respondent State is to pay, within three months, the following amounts, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement: (i) EUR 3,000 (three thousand euros) to the first applicant and EUR 1,500 (one thousand five hundred euros) each to the second and third applicants, plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of nonpecuniary damage; (ii) EUR 850 (eight hundred and fifty euros) to the first applicant, plus any tax that may be chargeable to him, in respect of his costs and expenses, to be paid directly to the account of Mr T. Kalmykov; (b) that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amounts at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points; dismisses the remainder of the applicants' claims for just satisfaction.
